page.title: 11Ecology - Nesting Birds
page.content: The particular tilt of the sill which forms the island means that a wide variety of nesting sites is provided to fill the needs of a variety of species, from ledges on the vertical cliffs of the western side to the rough inaccessible stepped outcrops on the east, and including the turfy slopes and dense flat vegetation of the island plateau. Almost all the nesting birds of the Isle of May are seabirds who make full use of the abundant marine food supply in the Firth of Forth. The two main groups of birds on the Isle are; (i) the auks, which include the guillemots, razorbills and puffins, (ii) the gulls, which include the Kittiwake, Herring Gull, Black Headed Gull, Black Backed Gull and the Common Gull.
